<summary>

•  The transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems are not well understood, particularly in the context of ratchet systems, which are asymmetric periodic potentials where particles experience directed transport.

    •  The origins of interest in ratchet systems lie in considerations about extracting useful work from unbiased noisy fluctuations, as seen in biological systems.

•  Recent attention has been focused on the behavior of deterministic chaotic ratchets and Hamiltonian ratchets, which are defined as systems that are sensitively dependent on initial conditions.

    •  The behavior of nonlinear systems, including the transition from regular to chaotic behavior, is generally sensitively dependent on the parameters of the system.

•  A study by Mateos considered a specific ratchet model with a periodically forced underdamped particle and found that the current could be either positive or negative depending on the amplitude of the periodic forcing.

    •  Mateos conjectured a connection between the reversal of current direction and a bifurcation from chaotic to periodic behavior in the trajectory dynamics.

•  However, a later investigation by Barbi and Salerno argued that the Mateos conjecture was not a valid rule, even in the specific system considered by Mateos.

    •  They proposed an alternative origin for the current reversal, suggesting it was related to the different stability properties of the rotating periodic orbits of the system.

•  The study of the transport properties of chaotic ratchets is challenging due to the extreme dependence of the results on the statistics of the ensemble being considered.

    •  The authors of the paper report on studies on the properties of the current in a chaotic deterministic ratchet and show that the current depends significantly on the details of the initial ensemble.

•  They also show that it is important to discard transients in quantifying the current and that broad heuristics are rare in chaotic systems.

    •  The authors find that while they disagree with many of the details of Barbi and Salerno's results, the broader conclusion still holds, that it is possible to have current reversals in the absence of bifurcations from chaos to periodic behavior.

•  They propose a generalized version of Mateos' conjecture, stating that bifurcations for trajectory dynamics as a function of system parameter seem to be associated with abrupt changes in the current.

    •  The authors also find evidence for a rule of thumb that bifurcations correspond to sudden current changes (spikes or jumps) in the ensemble current.

*   The study suggests that the presence of a distant orbiting body could explain the observed acceleration in the HD 37605 system.

*   The study also finds that the HD 80606 system is the most eccentric extrasolar planet known, with an eccentricity of 0.933.

*   The study presents updated orbital fits for the four planets in the HD 3651, HD 37605, HD 80606, and HD 89744 systems.
    *   The study also presents new HET observations for HD 37605 and HD 89744.

*   The study uses test particle simulations to determine the regions in each system where additional planets could exist.
    *   The simulations show that there are regions in each system where additional planets could exist, but these regions are not detectable with current surveys.

*   The study concludes that the detection limits for additional planets are highly varied, depending on the observing strategy and the quality of the data.
    *   The study suggests that future surveys with higher precision and longer time baselines could detect additional planets in these systems.

*   Introduction to the Problem
    *   Colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities due to their planar property and mutual focusing.
    *   The singularities are weakened when the waves have a relative cross-polarization prior to collision.
    *   A solution by Chandrasekhar and Xanthopoulos (CX) shows a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity.
    *   The CX solution initiated a literature on the stability of horizons formed in spacetimes of CPW.

*   Stability of Cauchy Horizon
    *   Yurtsever showed that the CH in spacetimes of CPW is unstable against plane-symmetric perturbations.
    *   A linear perturbation analysis by CX also reveals an analogous result.
    *   Any perturbation applied to a CPW spacetime turns the CH into an essential singularity.
    *   The electromagnetic (EM) field itself can weaken the strength of a singularity in CPW.

*   Collision of EM Waves
    *   The collision of pure EM waves has a special significance in terms of singularity formation.
    *   A solution by Bell and Szekeres (BS) describes the collision of two linearly polarized step EM waves.
    *   The singularity formed in the interaction region of the BS solution is removable by a coordinate transformation.
    *   However, the solution possesses essential curvature singularities on the null boundaries.

*   Cross-Polarized Version of BS Solution
    *   The cross-polarized version of the BS solution (CPBS) has the nice feature that the Weyl scalars are all regular in the interaction region.
    *   Cross-polarization does not remove the singularities formed on the null boundaries.
    *   The CPBS solution is used as a test ground to justify the validity of a CH stability conjecture.
    *   The conjecture seems to be more economical in reaching a direct conclusion about the stability of a CH.

*   Stability Conjecture
    *   The CH stability conjecture due to Helliwell and Konkowski (HK) is defined as follows.
    *   For all maximally extended spacetimes with a CH, the backreaction due to a field will affect the horizon in one of three manners.
    *   The conjecture suggests that a test field should be put into the background geometry to study the reaction it will experience.

<summary>

*   Quantum systems can be correlated in ways that supersede classical descriptions, and these correlations can be classified into different types, including non-separability, Bell-nonlocality, and EPR-steering.
    *   Non-separability refers to states that cannot be expressed as a mixture of product-states of the constituents.
    *   Bell-nonlocality refers to states that violate a Bell inequality, demonstrating the violation of local causality.
*   EPR-steering is a phenomenon where one party can steer the state of the other party's system by measuring their own system.
    *   EPR-steering is a special case of the more general phenomenon of steering, which can occur even for separable states.
*   The paper investigates the EPR-steerability of two-qubit states with maximally mixed marginals, known as t-states.
    *   The authors construct a local hidden variable (LHV) model for these states, which describes measurable quantum correlations for all separable and a large portion of non-separable t-states.
*   The authors also derive two sufficient general conditions for EPR-steerability, which are examples of EPR-steering inequalities.
    *   These inequalities are further of interest in that they are asymmetric under the interchange of Alice and Bob's roles.
*   The authors conjecture that the LHV model is optimal for t-states, but this remains an open question.
    *   A natural extension of this work is to consider LHV models for arbitrary two-qubit states, incorporating knowledge of their steering ellipsoids.
*   The authors also discuss the possibility of generalizing the LHV models to arbitrary positive operator-valued measure (POVM) measurements.
    *   This is a difficult problem, even for the case of two-qubit Werner states, but the steering ellipsoid may provide some intuition for how to proceed.

• The concept of using a single electron's spin to encode binary information has not been conclusively attributed to a specific individual.
  • This idea was mentioned in casual conversations by Feynman, but concrete schemes for implementing spintronic logic gates did not exist until the mid-1990s.

• Encoding information in spin may have advantages, including lower power dissipation and immunity to stray electric fields.
  • Spin devices may also be faster, as they are limited by the spin flip time rather than the transit time of charges.

• A concrete scheme for realizing a classical universal logic gate (NAND) using three spins was proposed in 1994.
  • The system consists of three conduction band electrons confined in semiconductor quantum dots, with exchange interaction allowed only between nearest neighbor spins.

• The spin orientation in each quantum dot becomes a binary variable due to the magnetic field.
  • The ground state of the array has a specific spin configuration, with the output port being logic 0 when the two inputs are logic 1.

• However, the system has a problem with metastable states, where the output is stuck in a logic indeterminate state.
  • This is due to the bidirectional nature of exchange interaction, which prevents unidirectional flow of logic signals.

• A solution to this problem is to use a three-phase clock to propagate the input state through a linear array.
  • This involves lowering two adjacent barriers pairwise at the same time, allowing the input state to propagate unidirectionally.

• Reversible logic gates are also being explored as a way to overcome the Landauer barrier.
  • A logically and physically reversible quantum inverter using two exchange coupled spins was devised in 1996.

• Spin coherence times in solids are much larger than charge coherence times, making spin a preferred vehicle for encoding qubits.
  • All-optical quantum computing using spin to carry out quantum computing has also been proposed as a viable idea.

•  **Introduction to Cataclysmic Variables (CVs)**
	• CVs are short-period binaries containing a white dwarf primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary.
	• The secondary fills its Roche lobe and transfers mass to the white dwarf through the inner Lagrangian point.
	• The main features of the orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors include a lack of systems in the 2-3 hr period range and a sharp cutoff at around 77 minutes.

•  **Theoretical Models and the Period Minimum Problem**
	• Theoretical models have been unable to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cutoff and the observed shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cutoff.
	• The period minimum problem refers to the discrepancy between the theoretical and observed minimum orbital period in CVs.
	• Theoretical models predict an accumulation of systems near the period minimum, but this feature is not present in the observed distribution.

•  **Consequential Angular Momentum Loss (CAML) Mechanism**
	• The CAML mechanism involves the loss of angular momentum due to the mass transferred from the secondary.
	• The CAML efficiency is defined as the fraction of mass lost from the secondary that leaves the system.
	• The CAML mechanism can increase the period minimum, but even a maximal efficient CAML mechanism cannot increase the bounce period sufficiently.

•  **Deformation Effects and the Period Spike Problem**
	• Deformation effects, such as tidal deformation, can increase the period minimum.
	• An implausibly large deformation factor of around 1.18 is needed to obtain a bounce period of 78 minutes.
	• The period spike problem refers to the discrepancy between the theoretical and observed accumulation of systems near the period minimum.

•  **Model Populations and the Rejection Probability**
	• Model populations that include brighter systems with a far greater weight than expected in a simple magnitude-limited sample achieve similar values for the rejection probability.
	• Models designed to "wash out" the period spike by introducing a large spread of the CAML efficiency do generally better than population models based on donor stars that are subject to a large spread of intrinsic deformation factors.
	• The rejection probability decreases if the full WD mass spectrum is taken into account.

•  **Formation and Evolution of CVs**
	• Most CVs must have formed at long periods and evolved through the period gap to become short-period CVs.

*   Stephan's Quintet is a compact group of galaxies that has produced a highly disturbed intragroup medium through a complex sequence of interactions and harassment.
    *   The group has a large-scale intergalactic shock wave, first observed as a narrow filament in the radio continuum and subsequently detected in the X-ray.
    *   The high-velocity collision of an intruder galaxy, NGC 7318B, with the intergalactic medium of the group is believed to be responsible for the shock-heating of the X-ray emitting gas.
    *   Optical emission line ratios and observed broad linewidths provide evidence that the region is powered by strong shocks and not star formation.
    *   The group is composed of several galaxies, including NGC 7318A, NGC 7317, and NGC 7319, which are interacting with each other.

*   The Stephan's Quintet system has been observed in the mid-infrared using the Spitzer Space Telescope, revealing powerful and widespread emission of warm molecular hydrogen (H2) along the shock ridge.
    *   The H2 emission is detected in several lines, including the 0-0 s(0), s(1), s(2), s(3), s(4), and s(5) transitions.
    *   The emission is concentrated towards the north of the shock and follows the X-ray distribution in the main shock and the "bridge" structure.
    *   The H2 emission is not directly excited by the X-ray heating, as the X-ray luminosity from the shocked filaments is much lower than the H2 line luminosity.

*   The fine-structure lines of iron, neon, and silicon are also detected in the shock region, providing information about the conditions within the system.
    *   The iron and silicon lines are depleted onto dust grains, indicating that dust is not destroyed in the shock.
    *   The neon lines are not depleted onto dust, suggesting that neon is not much affected by the shock.
    *   The fine-structure line ratios indicate that the shock is formed where the intruding galaxy collides with a pre-existing tidal filament of HI gas.

*   The star-forming regions in the system are dominated by sq-A and 7318B-South, located at the extreme ends of the shock ridge.
    *   The regions dominated by warm H2 emission exhibit very low star formation rates, consistent with a turbulent model where H2 is significantly reheated and cool clouds are too short-lived

•  The current cosmological model, known as the concordance model, is described by the Friedmann-Robertson-Walker (FRW) metric, which assumes a homogeneous and isotropic universe. The model includes dark matter (DM) and dark energy (DE) as the main components, with DE being responsible for the accelerated expansion of the universe.

    •  The concordance model has several shortcomings, including the coincidence problem, which arises from the fact that the DM/DE ratio is of order unity at the present time, requiring a fine-tuning of the initial conditions at the Planck scale.

    •  To alleviate the coincidence problem, interacting DM/DE models have been proposed, where the interaction between DM and DE can solve the coincidence problem and satisfy the second law of thermodynamics.

    •  Observational evidence for interacting DM/DE models comes from various sources, including the Planck collaboration, which found evidence of the existence of interaction but with a low confidence level.

•  Future observational facilities and surveys will be crucial in testing the concordance model and constraining the interaction between DM and DE. These facilities include the Square Kilometre Array (SKA), the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), the Euclid satellite, and the Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST).

    •  The SKA will provide accurate redshifts of millions of sources over a wide range of redshifts, making it an ideal redshift survey for cosmological studies. The LSST will image 20 billion galaxies and stars over 20,000 square degrees of the sky, providing a wealth of data for cosmological studies.

    •  The Euclid satellite will map the extra-galactic sky with the resolution of the Hubble Space Telescope, providing photometric redshifts for galaxies and 50 million spectroscopic redshifts. The WFIRST will construct a narrow and deep galaxy redshift survey of 2000 square degrees, providing a comparable precision for the baryon acoustic oscillations derived angular diameter distances and Hubble constant redshift evolution.

•  Combining the data from these facilities will provide a better understanding of the nature of DM, DE, and the interaction within the dark sectors. The combination of different observations will be particularly sensitive to signatures of modified gravity, and cross-correlating different data sets will help to control systematics for the primary science.

• Type 1 AGN spectra show a diversity of broad and narrow emission lines, providing insights into the structure and kinematics of photoionized gas in the vicinity of the central massive object.
		• Broad emission lines, such as Hα, are thought to arise in or near an accretion disk acting as the fuel reservoir for the central supermassive black hole.
• Two type 1 AGN populations have emerged, with population A showing smaller broad-line widths (FWHM Hα = 1000-4000) and population B showing larger broad-line widths (FWHM Hα = 4000-12000).
		• Population A sources are predominantly radio-quiet, while population B sources involve a mix of radio-quiet and radio-loud quasars.
• The Hα profile in population B sources shows two components: a "classical" broad component (BC) with zero or small shift, and a very broad and redshifted component (VBC).
		• The Hα profile in population A sources rarely shows a systematic red or blue shift above the FWHM profile level.
• The study of Fe II emission in type 1 quasars has led to the claim of a systematic redshift of Fe II relative to Hα, but this result is disputed.
		• The authors of the study argue that the Fe II redshift is due to the presence of He II emission, which was not included in the original fits.

*   **Introduction to Nuclear Multifragmentation**
    *   *Nuclear multifragmentation is a process where a nucleus breaks into multiple fragments due to high-energy collisions.*
    *   *The process is studied both theoretically and experimentally to understand the phase transition in nuclear matter.*
    *   *Theoretical calculations started in the 1980s, while the first experimental evaluation was reported in 1995 by the ALADIN group.*

*   **Improvements to the Microcanonical Multifragmentation Model**
    *   *The model was improved by refining the primary break-up part and including the secondary particle emission.*
    *   *The new version of the model preserves the general aspect of the caloric curve, with an important plateau-like region.*
    *   *The model can simultaneously fit the "definitory" characteristics of the nuclear multifragmentation phenomenon.*

*   **Comparison with Experimental Data**
    *   *The model was used to evaluate the equilibrated source sequence and compare it with experimental data.*
    *   *The agreement between the calculated heli isotopic temperature curve and the experimental data is excellent.*
    *   *The model predicts a nonequilibrium part of the experimentally evaluated excitation energy growing with the increase of the bombarding energy.*

*   **Conclusion**
    *   *The improved microcanonical multifragmentation model can accurately describe the nuclear multifragmentation process.*
    *   *The model can be used to study the phase transition in nuclear matter and provide insights into the behavior of nuclear matter at high energies.*
    *   *Further improvements to the model can be made to better understand the complex processes involved in nuclear multifragmentation.*
</summary>

*   The quiet solar corona is heated to a temperature of about 12 million kelvins, while the visible surface of the sun is roughly 250 times cooler.
    *   The primary energy source for this heating lies in the convection zone below the solar photosphere.
*   The debate centers on whether the energy to heat the corona derives from dissipation of magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) waves or from numerous small-scale magnetic reconnection events giving rise to nanoflares.
    *   The interaction of the magnetic field with convective flows in or below the photosphere can produce two types of magnetic disturbances in coronal structures.
*   The setup for searching for high-frequency coronal oscillations involves the mid-sized coronagraph at Lomnicky Peak Observatory.
    *   The coronagraph is equipped with a fast optical automatic guider and a special opto-mechanical interface between the coronagraph and the SECIS instrument.
*   The SECIS instrument is a high-performance camera designed specifically for scientific and machine vision applications.
    *   The camera has a monochrome 512x512 pixel frame transfer CCD and can be driven at a non-interlaced frame rate up to 70 frames per second.
*   Preliminary tests of the entire system were performed in April 2009, and the results showed that the image quality was very good and the noise level was low.
    *   The instrument itself is ready to measure prominent active region coronal loops above the solar limb when they appear under coronal "skies".
*   The SECIS instrument installed at the Lomnicky Peak Observatory Lyot coronagraph will allow data to be acquired that may result in an improved knowledge of where in the corona MHD waves are generated and/or dissipated.
    *   The signatures of high-frequency MHD waves involved in coronal heating may be observed.
*   The research has made use of NASA's Astrophysics Data System and was supported by the Slovak Research and Development Agency and the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education.
    *   The authors acknowledge the anonymous referee for comments that helped to improve the paper.

• Water vapor is an important molecule in interstellar and circumstellar clouds, and its chemistry is crucial for understanding these environments.
	• The 6.0-5.0 masing transition of H2O at 22 GHz has been used to trace high-excitation gas around star-forming regions and evolved stars.
	• However, the size of the emitting regions at this frequency is typically a few milliarcseconds, limiting the information obtained on the role of H2O at large spatial scales.
	• Other H2O lines have been detected from ground or airborne telescopes, including the 3.1-2.1 transition at 183 GHz and the 5.2-4.2 transition at 325 GHz.
		• The 183 GHz line has been used to map the emission of H2O at very large spatial scales, while the 325 GHz line has been detected in the direction of Orion IRC2 and other molecular clouds.

• **Introduction to Threshold Nets**
	• Threshold nets are constructed by assigning weights to nodes from a distribution and connecting nodes whose combined weights exceed a certain threshold.
	• They can be produced with arbitrary degree distributions, including scale-free, and encompass various architectures.

• **Properties of Threshold Nets**
	• Threshold nets have a diameter of 1 or 2, regardless of the number of nodes.
	• They are limited in some ways, but have desirable attributes such as modularity and easily computable structural measures.

• **Sequence Nets**
	• Sequence nets are a broader class of nets constructed from a sequence of letters and deterministic rules of connectivity.
	• They retain the desirable attributes of threshold nets and have a higher degree of compressibility.

• **Two-Letter Sequence Nets**
	• Two-letter sequence nets can be constructed from a two-letter alphabet and have three equivalence classes.
	• The classes have a high degree of modularity and various structural properties can be computed easily.

• **Three-Letter Sequence Nets**
	• Three-letter sequence nets can be derived from a three-letter alphabet and have 30 distinct equivalence classes.
	• They retain many desirable properties of threshold and two-letter sequence nets.

• **Symmetries in Sequence Nets**
	• Sequence nets have symmetries such as permutation and time reversal, which can be used to reduce the number of distinct rules.
	• The inverse of a graph is also a graph, and the complement of a threshold rule applied to the complement sequence yields back the original graph.

• **Structural Properties of Sequence Nets**
	• The degree of nodes in sequence nets can be calculated easily.
	• The distance between nodes in sequence nets can be determined based on the sequence and the rule used to construct the net.

• **Eigenvalues of Sequence Nets**
	• The eigenvalues of sequence nets are not integer and cannot be easily computed.
	• The second smallest and largest eigenvalues are important for dynamical properties and can be approximated using the average degree of the graph.

• **Mapping Sequence Nets to Threshold Nets**
	• Sequence nets can be mapped to generalized threshold nets, where connectivity is decided by the difference of weights rather than their sum.
	• This mapping may be helpful in analyzing some properties of sequence nets.

• **Open Questions and Future Work**
	• There are numerous open questions regarding sequence nets, including the possibility of reducing the number of distinct rules and finding systematic ways to map sequence nets to threshold nets.
	• Future work may involve tackling these

    •  The paper explores the use of compound Poisson subordinators in constructing nonconvex penalty functions. It studies two families of nonnegative random variables: nonnegative continuous random variables and nonnegative discrete random variables.

    •  The paper develops the ECME algorithms for solving sparse learning problems based on the nonconvex log, exp, LFR, and CEL penalties. It conducts experimental comparison with the state-of-the-art approach and shows that the nonconvex penalization approach is potentially useful in high-dimensional Bayesian modeling.

•  The study of high-temperature superconductivity in cuprates and the possibility of exotic gap symmetry has led to a renewed effort to find novel experimental probes of order parameter symmetry.

    •  The nonlinear current response of d-wave superconductors was proposed as a potential probe, and it was predicted that an anisotropy in the nonlinear current would exist due to the presence of nodes in the order parameter.

    •  However, early experimental work did not verify these predictions, and it was suggested that impurity scattering or nonlocal effects may be responsible.

    •  A more recent reanalysis of experiment has claimed to confirm the predictions, and an alternative proposal was given by Dahm and Scalapino, who examined the quadratic term in the magnetic response of the penetration depth.

•  The study of two-band superconductors has also been a focus of research, with the material MGB being a promising candidate for a classic two-band electron-phonon superconductor.

    •  The goal of the study is to compare the differences between one-band and two-band s-wave superconductors in terms of their nonlinear response.

    •  The study involves re-examining the one-band case and discovering new effects due to strong electron-phonon coupling at both high and low temperatures.

    •  The study also examines the situation for two-band superconductors, starting from a case of highly decoupled bands and looking for signatures of the low-energy scale due to the smaller gap.

•  The study provides a prediction for the nonlinear coefficient in MGB using the parameters set by band structure calculations.

    •  The bands in MGB are found to be quite integrated, and the nonlinear coefficient is monotonically increasing in contrast to a previous prediction.

    •  The increased nonlinearity due to the smaller gap is found to be best reduced by adding impurities to the smaller gap band.

    •  The study also finds that the nonlinearity is greatly increased when the supercurrent samples the c-axis direction.

•  The study provides several simple formulas for near Tc which aid in the understanding of the range of behavior observed in the numerical calculations.

    •  The study awaits experimental verification of its predictions.

    •  The study thanks several researchers for their contributions and acknowledges funding from various sources.

    •  The study was supported in part by the National Science Foundation under grant number DMR02-11166.

</summary>

•  **Classification Problem in Time Series Data Mining**
    • Classification problem is one of the most important tasks in time series data mining.

•  **1-Nearest Neighbor (1-nn) with Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) Distance**
    • 1-nn with DTW distance is one of the best classifiers for time series data.

•  **Importance of Distance Measure Selection**
    • Selecting an appropriate distance measure is crucial for 1-nn classification.

•  **DTW Distance vs. Euclidean Distance**
    • DTW distance is more appropriate and produces more accurate results than Euclidean distance.

•  **Sakoe-Chiba Band (S-C Band) and Ratanamahatana-Keogh Band (R-K Band)**
    • S-C band is used to speed up DTW calculation and as a global constraint.
    • R-K band is introduced to generalize the global constraint model and allows great flexibility.

•  **Proposed Learning Algorithms**
    • Two new learning algorithms are proposed to discover the best multi R-K bands: band boundary extraction and iterative learning.

•  **LB_Keogh Lower Bound**
    • LB_Keogh lower bound is used to speed up the computation in the prediction step.

•  **Silhouette Index**
    • Silhouette index is used as a heuristic function for selecting the band that yields the best prediction accuracy.
</summary>

• Entanglement dynamics in a system of two qubits interacting with two amplitude-damping reservoirs has been studied. The results show that the entanglement can be stably distributed among all bipartite subsystems, which is different from the Markovian approximate result and the decoherenceless double Jaynes-Cummings model result.

    • The entanglement distribution is dependent on the explicit property of the reservoir and its coupling to the qubit, and the non-Markovian effect plays an important role in the entanglement dynamics.

• The entanglement invariance identity is satisfied at any time, which implies that the entanglement is not destroyed but re-distributed among all bipartite subsystems in a certain invariant manner.

    • The entanglement distribution in the steady state has been studied by taking the reservoir as a photonic band gap (PBG) medium, and the results show that a stable entanglement can be formed among all bipartite subsystems when the bound states between the qubit and the reservoir are available.

• Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are powerful flashes of gamma-rays lasting from less than one second to tens of seconds, with isotropic distribution in the sky.
  • They are observed above the terrestrial atmosphere with X-ray gamma-ray detectors aboard satellites.
  • The origin of GRBs is still lacking an explanation, with possible explanations including the collapse of a very massive star (hypernova) and the coalescence of one compact binary system.

• The detection of gravitational waves (GWs) associated with GRBs is a promising area of research, with the possibility of detecting GW bursts using present resonant detectors.
  • The duration of a GW burst is predicted to be of the order of a few milliseconds for a variety of sources, including the coalescing and merging black holes and/or neutron star binaries.
  • The amplitude of the GW burst associated with a total conversion of 1-2 solar masses should have an amplitude of the order of 10^-22.

• A program was launched to study the presence of correlations between GRB events detected with BeppoSAX and the output signals from gravitational antennas Nautilus and Explorer.
  • The analysis used an algorithm based on cross-correlating the outputs of two GW detectors, coping with the problem of the unknown possible time difference between GRB and GW bursts.
  • The rome group operates two resonant bar detectors: Explorer and Nautilus.

• The experimental method and the model for the averaged correlation at zero delay time were presented, and the values of GW amplitude consistent with the observation were inferred.

• The Bayesian approach was used to infer the GW amplitude, with a uniform distribution as prior for the GW amplitude.

• New experimental upper limits have been determined for the burst intensity causing correlations of GWs with GRBs.

•  The traditional two-step process for hadron production at large transverse momentum involves a hard scattering of partons followed by fragmentation of the scattered parton to the detected hadron. However, this process is inadequate for the production of particles at intermediate transverse momentum in heavy-ion collisions.

    •  In heavy-ion collisions, recombination of partons is shown to be a more appropriate hadronization process, especially when soft partons are involved.

•  The purpose of this paper is to introduce the notion of shower partons and determine their distributions in order to represent the phenomenological fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.

    •  Shower partons are defined as partons that are initiated by a hard parton and can either recombine among themselves or recombine with soft partons in the environment.

•  The authors aim to quantify the properties of shower partons and illustrate the importance of their recombination with thermal partons.

    •  The recombination model is used to describe the hadronization process, and the shower parton distributions are determined from the fragmentation functions using a fitting procedure.

• A new local optimization method is proposed for solving nonconvex semidefinite programming problems. The method involves approximating the nonconvex feasible set by a sequence of inner positive semidefinite convex approximation sets.

    • The algorithm is a generalization of the inner convex approximation method and is modified by using a regularization technique to ensure strict descent.
    • The advantages of this algorithm are that it is simple to implement and does not require a globalization strategy such as a line-search procedure.
    • The convergence of the algorithm to a stationary point is investigated under mild conditions.

• The proposed method is applied to solve optimization problems with bilinear matrix inequality (BMI) constraints, which are known to be nonconvex and NP-hard.

    • The method can be used to solve various problems in static output feedback controller design, including sparse linear static output feedback controller design, spectral abscissa and pseudospectral abscissa optimization, and mixed synthesis optimization.
    • The algorithm is tested on several problems in the compbib library and compared with the convex-concave decomposition method.
    • The results show that the proposed method can solve the problems efficiently and effectively.

• The proposed method can be extended to solve more general nonconvex semidefinite programming problems where an inner positive semidefinite convex approximation of the feasible set can be found.

    • This is a future research direction and the method can be applied to various fields such as control theory, optimization, and machine learning.
    • The method can be used to solve complex optimization problems that are difficult to solve using traditional methods.
    • The proposed method has the potential to be a powerful tool for solving nonconvex optimization problems in various fields.
</summary>

• **Discrete Differential Geometry and Dirac-Kähler Formulation**
	+ The Dirac-Kähler formulation of fermionic field theory uses the antisymmetry inherent in the product between differential forms to describe the Clifford algebra.
	+ Discrete differential geometry schemes have been proposed to regularize calculations, but defining such a scheme has proven to be challenging.

• **Geometric Discretization of Dirac-Kähler Fermions**
	+ The geometric discretization of Dirac-Kähler fermions involves introducing a complex, which comprises points, links, faces, volumes, and hyper-volumes between points.
	+ The discretization of the Dirac-Kähler operator and the Hodge star operator is crucial for implementing chiral symmetry and flavour projection.

• **Chiral and Flavour Projection**
	+ Chiral projection can be implemented using the original and dual complexes, while flavour projection requires the introduction of additional complexes, including the 12c and 12cd complexes.
	+ The path integral can be evaluated separately on each complex, and the form of the path integral prior to flavour projection is equivalent to that used in the quarter-root trick of lattice QCD.

</summary>

<summary>

• **Introduction to Cognitive Radio Systems**
	• The efficient use of scarce spectrum in wireless applications has led to interest in cognitive radio systems.
	• Cognitive radio networks allow secondary users to transmit concurrently with primary users as long as interference power is kept below a certain limit.
	• The broadcast nature of wireless transmissions makes wireless communications vulnerable to eavesdropping.

• **Secure Transmission in Cognitive Radio Networks**
	• The problem of secure transmission in the presence of an eavesdropper was first studied from an information-theoretic perspective.
	• Wyner's wiretap channel model was extended to the Gaussian channel.
	• Information-theoretic security has been investigated in fading multi-antenna and multiuser channels.

• **Collaborative Relay Beamforming in Cognitive Radio Networks**
	• The secrecy capacity is defined as the maximum achievable rate from the transmitter to the legitimate receiver.
	• The optimal beamforming solution that maximizes the secrecy rate in the cognitive relay channel can be obtained by using semidefinite programming.
	• Two sub-optimal null space beamforming schemes are proposed to simplify the analysis.

• **Numerical Results**
	• Numerical results show that the suboptimal null space beamforming achievable rates are very close to the corresponding optimal ones.
	• Imposing individual relay power constraints leads to small losses in the secrecy rates.
	• The secrecy rate achieved by beamforming in the null space of both the eavesdropper's and primary user's channels is almost insensitive to different interference temperature limits.

• **Conclusion**
	• Collaborative relay beamforming in cognitive radio networks is studied under secrecy constraints.
	• Optimal beamforming designs that maximize secrecy rates are investigated under both total and individual relay power constraints.
	• Two sub-optimal null space beamforming schemes are proposed to simplify the computation.
</summary>

• The Maxwell equation's @xmath0-invariance was discovered by Cunningham and Bateman a century ago, but it is broken when using the Lorenz gauge for quantization due to gauge freedom.

    • This breaking of symmetry might seem to lack physical meaning, but it is often overlooked.
    • The purpose of the present paper is to demonstrate the benefits of keeping this fundamental symmetry when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS).

• A classical @xmath0-invariant field cannot distinguish between two CFS locally, so why not maintain the @xmath0-invariance during the quantization process in a CFS?

    • Doing so, a free field living in a CFS might behave like in a flat space, and the corresponding Wightman two-point functions can be related to their Minkowskian counterparts.
    • The work confirms this assertion in the special case of the Maxwell field in de Sitter space.

• The paper uses Dirac's six-cone formalism and realizes all CFS as intersections of the null cone and a given surface in a six-dimensional Lorentzian space.

    • The introduction of auxiliary fields and the use of the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme are necessary to deal with gauge freedom of the Maxwell field.
    • Another important ingredient is the use of a well-suited coordinate system, which allows to get a Minkowskian form for @xmath0-invariant CFS formulas.

• The main result is a set of Wightman two-point functions for Maxwell and auxiliary fields.

    • The paper is organized as follows: [Geom] sets the coordinate systems and the geometrical construction of CFS, [Fields] defines the fields and gives their dynamical equations, and [Quantum-Field] solves the dynamical system, constructs the quantum field, and writes down the two-point functions.

    • Some technical details are given in Appendix [Details].

• The infinitesimal @xmath0 action on the fields is expanded in Appendix [Action], and their @xmath0-invariant scalar product is given.

    • The six-dimensional Lorentzian space is provided with the natural orthogonal coordinates and equipped with the metric.
    • Quantities related to this space and its null cone are labeled with a tilde.

• The paper shows how to obtain the @xmath0-invariant Maxwell field in a CFS from a six-dimensional one-form.

• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices fire chips to their neighbors if possible.
	• The game is governed by rules where at each move, a vertex fires exactly one chip to each neighbor if it has at least as many chips as it has neighbors.
	• The position of the game is denoted by an ordered pair containing the graph and the number of chips on each vertex.
	• The game is a special case of the general chip-firing game and has connections to number theory, algebra, and combinatorics.

• The parallel chip-firing game has been studied on various graphs, including trees, complete graphs, and complete bipartite graphs.
	• Bitar and Goles showed that the period of any position on a tree graph is 1 or 2.
	• Kominers and Kominers showed that all connected graphs satisfying certain conditions have period 1.
	• Levine proved that the complete graph has periods that are at most 2.

• The parallel chip-firing game has been used to simulate classical computers and solve computationally solvable problems.
	• Goles and Margenstern showed that it can simulate any two-register machine.
	• The game can also be used to simulate a pile of particles that falls whenever there are too many particles stacked at any point.

• The parallel chip-firing game has implications for statistical physics and the study of self-organized criticality.
	• The game demonstrates the phenomenon of self-organized criticality, tending towards a "critical state" in which slight perturbations cause large disturbances.
	• The game has been used to study the behavior of particles in a deterministic fixed-energy sandpile.

• The authors have established some lemmas about parallel chip-firing games on general simple connected graphs.
	• They have bounded the number of chips on any single vertex in games with nontrivial period.
	• They have defined the notion of a complement position and shown that it has the same behavior as the original position.
	• They have found a necessary and sufficient condition for a period to occur.

• The authors have found every possible period for the complete bipartite graph.
	• They have shown that the only possible periods are of length 2 or 3 for n ≥ 3.
	• They have constructed games with such periods and proved their main result.

• The authors have constructed positions on the complete 2-partite graph with period n for all n.

•  The formation of a black hole (BH) in a short gamma-ray burst (GRB) has been observed for the first time, providing new insights into the physics of these events.

    •  The observation was made possible by the detection of high-energy gamma rays from the GRB 090510, which was triggered by the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope.

•  The data analysis suggests that the GRB 090510 is a short GRB originating from a binary neutron star (NS) merger, with a redshift of 0.903.

    •  The analysis also reveals a new structure in the thermal emission of the prompt gamma-ray burst (p-GRB) emission, followed by the onset of the GeV emission linked to the BH formation.

•  The study provides evidence for the formation of a Kerr-Newman BH from the merger of two massive NSs in a binary system, with a mass of approximately 2.5 solar masses.

    •  The results have implications for our understanding of the physics of GRBs and the formation of BHs in these events, and may also shed light on the properties of BHs in general.

•  The study also suggests that the GeV emission in GRBs is related to the presence of a BH and its activity, and that the BH formation is a key process in the evolution of these events.

    •  The findings have important implications for the study of GRBs and BHs, and may also have implications for our understanding of the physics of the universe.

</summary>

*   The Standard Model (SM) is used to limit models with physics beyond the SM by performing global fits to precision measurements. The SM predicts the mass of the W boson in terms of other parameters, which are strongly correlated with the top quark mass.
    *   The SM tree-level relation is broken in models with new physics, requiring extra input parameters when renormalized at one loop.
*   The SM with an additional real scalar triplet (triplet model) is considered, which has been studied at one-loop by Blank and Hollik. The triplet model has four fundamental parameters, requiring a fourth input parameter in a consistent renormalization scheme.
    *   The @xmath3 boson mass in the triplet model depends on the top quark mass logarithmically and on the scalar masses quadratically.
*   The left-right (LR) symmetric model is considered as a second example to show that new physics does not decouple from the SM at one-loop. The LR model has five fundamental parameters in the gauge/higgs sector, requiring a fourth input parameter.
    *   The counterterm for the weak mixing angle in the LR model is given, and the contribution of the lightest neutral higgs is suppressed by the heavy gauge boson masses.

</summary>

• A choice of nonconstant meromorphic function on a compact Riemann surface realizes the surface as a finite-sheeted branched covering of the Riemann sphere.

    • This is related to the concept of log-Riemann surfaces, which are certain branched coverings of the Riemann sphere by a punctured compact Riemann surface.

• Log-Riemann surfaces were defined and studied in the context of transcendental functions of infinite degree.

    • They are given by a pair consisting of a Riemann surface and a local holomorphic diffeomorphism to the Riemann sphere, with a discrete set of points added to the surface.

• A log-Riemann surface is of finite type if it has finitely many ramification points and a finitely generated fundamental group.

    • Uniformization theorems were proved for log-Riemann surfaces of finite type, which imply that such a surface is given by a pair consisting of a compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function on the punctured surface.

• The uniformization theorems imply that a log-Riemann surface of finite type is given by a pair consisting of a compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function on the punctured surface.

    • The meromorphic function has exponential singularities at the punctures, and the types of these singularities are given by equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions modulo germs of holomorphic functions.

• The uniformization theorems also imply that the map from the space of meromorphic sections of a line bundle to the space of functions with exponential singularities is an isomorphism.

    • This isomorphism preserves divisors, and it gives a one-to-one correspondence between exp-algebraic structures on a compact Riemann surface and degree-zero line bundles on the surface with meromorphic connections.

</summary>

*   Recent progress in understanding physics of strongly correlated electronic systems has been made through the development of dynamical mean field theory (DMFT).
    *   DMFT is a computationally tractable many-body technique that can be merged with realistic local density approximation (LDA) based electronic structure calculations.
    *   This combination is promising due to its simplicity and correctness in both band and atomic limits.
    *   Efforts are being made to develop a LDA+DMFT method, LDA++ approach, combined GW and DMFT theory, spectral density functional theory, and other methods.

*   The goal is to explore all space of parameters where neither doping nor degeneracy is kept fixed.
    *   This is crucial for calculating properties of realistic solid-state systems where bandwidth and interaction strength are not known at the beginning.
    *   The ideology of model Hamiltonians is different, where the input set of parameters defines the regime of correlations.
    *   Realistic DMFT simulations of material properties require fast scans of the entire parameter space.

*   The quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) technique is very accurate but has limitations.
    *   It can cope with multiorbital situations but not with multiplet interactions.
    *   Its applicability has been limited to a small number of orbitals or unphysically large temperatures due to its computational cost.
    *   Impurity solvers that improve upon the NCA approximation have been developed, but they have not been able to retrieve Fermi liquid behavior at very low temperatures.

*   A new interpolative approach for the self-energy in the general multiorbital situation is proposed.
    *   This approach is not an attempt to develop an alternative method for solving the impurity problem but rather a follow-up of the ideology of LDA theory.
    *   The approach is based on rational interpolation and uses a set of constraints to determine the coefficients of the interpolation.
    *   The constraints are derived from the atomic limit, Friedel sum rule, quasiparticle mass renormalization, and positions of Hubbard bands.

*   The slave boson mean-field (SBMF) approach and the Hubbard I approximation are used to determine the functional dependence of the coefficients upon doping, degeneracy, and interaction strength.
    *   The SBMF approach can predict the parameters of interpolation with good accuracy, while the Hubbard I method fails in some regimes.

* The study of nonequilibrium phase transitions is a topic of growing interest due to its application to complex systems. The ZGB model, which describes the oxidation of a catalytic surface, is a specific model used to study these transitions.
	* The original ZGB model is an irreversible lattice model based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, where reactants must be adsorbed before reacting.
	* The model has been studied using mean-field theory, simulations, and Monte Carlo methods, and has been found to exhibit two phase transitions between active and poisoned states.
* The introduction of inert sites into the ZGB model affects the phase transitions and the production rate of CO molecules.
	* The site and pair approximations were used to study the effects of inert sites on the phase diagram of the ZGB model.
	* Monte Carlo simulations were also performed to check the results obtained in the site and pair approximations.

•  The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems in the crystal lattice, which is a generalization of the classical lattice.

    •  The authors extend the problems of the hydrodynamic limit to the case where the underlying space has geometric structures, specifically the crystal lattice.

•  The crystal lattice is a generalization of the classical lattice, square lattice, triangular lattice, hexagonal lattice, kagom lattice, and diamond lattice.

    •  The authors motivate the study of these problems by citing the scaling limit of interacting particle systems, which has its origins in statistical mechanics and hydrodynamics.

•  The hydrodynamic limit for the exclusion process is one of the most studied models in this context, and the authors provide an example of the exclusion process in the integer lattice.

    •  The authors discuss the relationship between macroscopic behaviors of particles and geometric structures of the underlying spaces, and they deal with the crystal lattice, which is the simplest extension of the Euclidean lattice.

•  The authors construct a scaling limit of a crystal lattice by taking a finite index subgroup of the free abelian group acting on the lattice.

    •  They embed the quotient graph into a torus and obtain exclusion processes embedded by the embedding map into the torus.

•  The authors deal with the simplest case among exclusion processes, the symmetric simple exclusion process, and its perturbation, the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process.

    •  They obtain a heat equation with nonlinear drift terms on the torus as the limit of the process of empirical density.

•  The authors prove the local ergodic theorem, which is the key step of the proof, by using the one-block estimate and the two-block estimate.

    •  They derive the quasi-linear parabolic equation by applying the local ergodic theorem and complete the proof of the main theorem.

•  The authors mention related works, including the hydrodynamic limit on spaces other than the Euclidean lattice and interacting particle systems evolving in random environments.

    •  They conclude that the hydrodynamic limit for the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process on the crystal lattice is obtained as an extension of the one on the Euclidean lattice.

*   Myles Hollander's academic journey began at Carnegie Mellon, where he initially studied metallurgical engineering but switched to mathematics after being encouraged by the math department chair, David Moscovitz.
    *   Hollander's interest in statistics was sparked by a course taught by Morrie DeGroot, which was based on Mood's "Introduction to the Theory of Statistics."
*   Hollander's graduate studies at Stanford University had a significant impact on his career choices and statistical directions, and he was part of a talented cohort of students that included Brad Efron, Howie Taylor, and Grace Wahba.
    *   Hollander's thesis was devoted to rank tests for ordered alternatives in the two-way layout, and he proposed a test based on a sum of overlapping signed rank statistics that is not strictly distribution-free but can be made asymptotically distribution-free.
*   Hollander's collaborations with Frank Proschan and Jayaram Sethuraman led to significant contributions in nonparametric statistics, including the development of the DT (decreasing in transposition) paper and the study of repair models in reliability.
    *   Hollander and Sethuraman's work on repair models in reliability led to the development of a general class of models for recurrent events, which includes many models that have been proposed in reliability and survival analysis.
*   Hollander's service as the chair of the Department of Statistics at Florida State University was marked by his efforts to recruit top talent, broaden the department's focus, and promote interdisciplinary work.
    *   Hollander's legacy at Florida State University includes the establishment of the FSU-UF biannual statistics colloquium series and the creation of a new M.S. and Ph.D. program in biostatistics.

• The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is a topological invariant that can be computed for line arrangements. It has various applications, including distinguishing between connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces.

    • The Zariski-Lefschetz hyperplane section theorem states that the fundamental group of the complement of a hypersurface in a projective space can be computed using the fundamental group of the complement of a plane curve.
    • The search for Zariski pairs, which are pairs of plane curves with the same combinatorics but non-homeomorphic complements, requires the computation of fundamental groups.
    • The fundamental group of the complement of a line arrangement can be computed using the braid monodromy and the Moishezon-Teicher algorithm.

• Fan's conjecture states that if the fundamental group of the complement of a line arrangement is a direct sum of free groups and infinite cyclic groups, then the graph associated to the arrangement has no cycles.

    • The conjecture was proved by Eliyahu, Liberman, Schaps, and Teicher, and it has implications for the study of conjugation-free geometric presentations of fundamental groups.
    • A conjugation-free geometric presentation of a fundamental group is a presentation with certain properties, including the absence of conjugations in the relations.

• The paper aims to study the family of line arrangements whose fundamental groups have conjugation-free geometric presentations.

    • The authors show that the fundamental group of a real affine arrangement without parallel lines, whose graph has a unique cycle of length 3 and has no line with more than two multiple points, has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
    • They also generalize this result to arrangements whose graphs are cycles of any length and have no line with more than two multiple points.
    • The authors use the Moishezon-Teicher algorithm and the van Kampen theorem to compute the fundamental group of the complement of the arrangement.

• The paper also discusses the relation between the family of arrangements with conjugation-free geometric presentations and other families of arrangements, such as nice and simple arrangements.

    • The authors note that the fundamental group of the arrangement of n+2 lines whose graph consists of a unique cycle of length 3 has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
    • They also show that the fundamental group of the arrangement of n lines whose graph consists of a unique cycle of length n has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.

•  **Introduction to Flavor Symmetry**
	•  Flavor symmetry is a concept in particle physics that aims to explain the mass and mixing patterns of fermions.
	•  Researchers have been interested in finding flavor symmetry to describe the mass and mixing patterns of fermions.
	•  Continuous and discrete symmetries have been explored to achieve this goal.

•  **Tri-Bimaximal Mixing Pattern**
	•  The tri-bimaximal mixing pattern is a specific mixing pattern that has been observed in neutrino oscillation experiments.
	•  This pattern is characterized by three mixing angles: θ12, θ23, and θ13.
	•  The tri-bimaximal mixing pattern is a natural consequence of certain flavor symmetries.

•  **Altarelli-Feruglio Model**
	•  The Altarelli-Feruglio model is a specific model that incorporates the tri-bimaximal mixing pattern.
	•  This model involves a discrete symmetry group and a set of scalar fields that generate the required vacuum alignment.
	•  The model predicts a hierarchical mass spectrum for charged leptons and quasi-degenerate or hierarchical neutrino masses.

•  **CP Violation and Leptogenesis**
	•  CP violation is a phenomenon that can occur in the leptonic sector, leading to a non-zero Dirac CP phase.
	•  Leptogenesis is a mechanism that can generate the baryon asymmetry of the universe through the decay of right-handed neutrinos.
	•  The Altarelli-Feruglio model predicts a non-zero Dirac CP phase and can generate leptogenesis.

•  **Soft Breaking of Flavor Symmetry**
	•  Soft breaking of flavor symmetry is a mechanism that can generate non-zero CP violation and leptogenesis.
	•  This mechanism involves introducing small perturbations to the Dirac neutrino mass matrix.
	•  The soft breaking of flavor symmetry can lead to a deviation from the tri-bimaximal mixing pattern.

•  **Explicit Breaking of Flavor Symmetry**
	•  Explicit breaking of flavor symmetry is a mechanism that can generate non-zero CP violation and leptogenesis.
	•  This mechanism involves introducing a small parameter to the Dirac neutrino mass matrix.
	•  The explicit breaking of flavor symmetry can lead to a deviation from the tri-bimaximal mixing pattern.

    • They are composed of both organic and inorganic components, where the organic part forms the active part of the device and the inorganic part provides electrical contact.
    • The electronic structure of the interface between these two parts plays a crucial role in determining the final device performance.
    • Charge transfer between the organic and inorganic components and the energies at which the transfer takes place need to be understood carefully.

• The calculation of charge transfer energies is challenging, especially in the single-molecule limit.

    • The quasiparticle (QP) description is commonly used to calculate the addition and removal energies, but it has limitations.
    • Density functional theory (DFT) is often used to calculate the energy levels of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), but it has its own limitations.
    • Constrained DFT (CDFT) is a more resource-efficient alternative that can be used to calculate charge transfer energies.

• CDFT has been used to study the adsorption of benzene molecules on a 2D metal, specifically graphene.

    • The calculations show that the addition and removal energies decrease in absolute value as the molecule is brought closer to the graphene sheet.
    • A classical electrostatic model can be used to describe the image charge formation and its effect on the charge transfer energies.
    • The presence of defects in the graphene sheet does not significantly alter the charge transfer energies.

• The charge transfer energies depend on the distance between the molecule and the graphene sheet.

    • The image charge formation is responsible for this dependence.
    • CDFT can capture this effect, but standard Kohn-Sham DFT cannot.

    • The classical electrostatic model can be used to describe this effect.
    • The level renormalization is different from that on a perfect metal due to the finite dielectric constant of graphene.

    *   Many-body effects appear in diverse systems such as nuclear matter, superconductivity, colloidal suspensions, quantum-electrodynamic Casimir forces, polymers, nematic colloids, and noble gases with van der Waals forces acting among them.
    *   These effects can be described by effective interactions among the large particles, which are inherently not pairwise additive.

*   The concept of an atomic clock and its operation is discussed, highlighting the need for an active oscillator in addition to the passive atoms.
    *   The resonance exhibited by the atoms varies with the construction and operation of the clock, and the oscillator drifts in relation to its setting.
    *   The SI second is defined as the resonance that would be found at absolute zero temperature, and a wave function is chosen to express the relation between measured and imagined resonances.
    *   The wave function incorporated into the operation of an atomic clock can never be unconditionally known, and this unknowability has implications for the second as a unit of measurement.

*   The distinction between explanation and evidence in quantum theory is discussed, and the language of quantum theory is shown to reflect this distinction.
    *   Explanations are offered by the linear algebra of wave functions and operators, while evidence is offered by probabilities on a set of outcomes.
    *   The distinction between linear operators and probabilities implies a gap between any explanation and the evidence explained.
    *   This gap means that no wave function can be unconditionally known, and not even probabilities of future evidence can be unconditionally foreseen.

    *   The open machine is used to model the logic of a computer that communicates with other devices in a feedback loop.

*   Moped is a patented algorithm for data compression and speeding up the evaluation of likelihood functions in astronomical data analysis.
    *   It eliminates the need for matrix inversion by compressing data into independent and unit variance values.
    *   This simplifies the likelihood calculation and provides orders of magnitude improvement in runtime.
    *   However, it may create erroneous peaks in the likelihood function, impeding parameter estimation.

*   Moped's limitations include multimodal and degenerate distributions, which can lead to incorrect peaks.
    *   The algorithm assumes a diagonal covariance matrix, which can cause a speed reduction.
    *   It may not accurately represent the likelihood function in certain scenarios.
    *   The solution to this problem is to use multiple fiducial models to create multiple sets of weighting vectors.

*   The algorithm's performance depends on the number of parameters and the complexity of the model.
    *   In some cases, adding more parameters can improve the situation, but not always.
    *   The benefit of using Moped comes when the procedure is significantly faster than mapping the original likelihood surface.
    *   However, if there are multiple intersections, it is necessary to map the original likelihood to know if they are due to degeneracy in the model or were created erroneously by Moped.

*   Solutions to the problem of erroneous peaks include comparing the original likelihoods of peak parameter values and using multiple fiducial models.
    *   The correct peak and any degeneracy in the original likelihood function will yield similar values to one another.
    *   A false peak in the Moped likelihood will have a much lower value in the original likelihood and can be ruled out.
    *   The solution presented in the paper is to use multiple fiducials to create multiple sets of weighting vectors and average the log-likelihood across these choices.

    *   The total gas mass is found to be (4.7±0.7)×10^22 M⊙.
    *   The channel maps provide evidence of well-ordered rotation throughout the disk.
    *   The intensity-weighted-mean velocity field exhibits symmetric structure in the outer disk.

*   The study models the Orion dwarf as consisting of two "luminous" components, namely the stellar and the gaseous disks, embedded in a dark halo.
    *   The stellar component is modeled as an exponential thin disk with a scale length of 1.33 kpc.
    *   The dynamical contribution of the gas to the observed rotation curve is derived from the total intensity map.
    *   The dark halo is considered to have two different parametrizations of the mass distribution: an NFW profile and the cored profile of the halo universal rotation curve (URCH).
    *   The URCH model yields a total rotation curve that fits the data extremely well.

*   The study tests the MOND formalism and finds that it is discrepant with the data if we adopt the literature galaxy distance and gas mass.
    *   The kinematic data can be reproduced in the MOND formalism if we allow for significant adjustments of the distance and/or value of the gas mass.

*   The trihydrogen dication, consisting of three protons and one electron, is a simple Coulomb system.
    *   Its stability has been studied intensely in the 1960s and 1970s.
    *   Conroy investigated the potential energy surfaces of the electronic ground state and lowest excited states.
    *   He concluded that the trihydrogen dication is not stable.
    *   Other researchers, such as Schwartz and Schaad, and Somorjai and Yue, reported single-point calculations but did not address the stability problem.

*   Berkowitz and Stocker searched for the ion through charge stripping experiments but could not find evidence of stable trihydrogen dication.
    *   Later, the issue was reconsidered from the theoretical side by Shoucri and Darling, and Hernández and Carb.
    *   They examined equilateral configurations with the variational linear combination of atomic orbitals (LCAO) method.
    *   Johnson and Poshusta reported another single-point calculation in the context of Gaussian basis set optimization.
    *   Ackermann et al. revisited the question about the existence of trihydrogen dication using the finite element method.

*   The authors excluded the possibility of stable trihydrogen dication in the electronic ground state.
    *   However, accurate ab initio results on the basis of which the non-existence of trihydrogen dication can be demonstrated are scarce and not convincing.
    *   The question is addressed again in the present study.
    *   One of the motivations of the study is related to the fact that trihydrogen dication in an equilateral triangular configuration may exist as a metastable state in a magnetic field.

*   The Schrödinger equation for the system is written as ψ(r) = Eψ(r), where r is the electron momentum, and E is the total energy.
    *   Atomic units are used throughout, although energies are expressed in Rydbergs (Ry).
    *   The goal is to study the stability of the molecular ion trihydrogen dication.
    *   If such an ion exists, it implies the existence of the ground state of the system.

*   Two methods are used to explore the system: (i) variational with physically relevant trial functions, and (ii) standard variational based on using standard Gaussian trial functions.
    *   Both methods lead to highly accurate quantitative results for total energy versus the size of the triangle.

• Recent investigations of galaxy distribution in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) have revealed a complex relationship between galaxy properties and their environments.
	• These investigations have found that galaxy clustering is a function of both star formation history and luminosity, with low-luminosity galaxies clustering strongly by color and luminous galaxies clustering strongly by luminosity.

• The study of galaxy environments as a function of luminosity and color has shown that red, low-luminosity galaxies tend to be in overdense regions, down to at least absolute magnitude -17.
	• This result extends previous findings towards lower luminosities by about 2 magnitudes.

• The study has also found that the dependence of mean environment on color persists to the lowest luminosities explored, and that a correlation function with a stronger amplitude implies a correlation function with a steeper slope.
	• In regions of a given overdensity on small scales, the overdensity on large scales does not appear to relate to the recent star formation history of the galaxies.

• The results of the study are consistent with the notion that only the masses of the host halos of the galaxies observed are strongly affecting the star formation of the galaxies.
	• The study therefore encourages the "halo model" description of galaxy formation and the pursuit of semi-analytic models which depend only on the properties of the host halo.
</summary>

*   **Introduction to Transverse Spin Fluctuations**
    *   Transverse spin fluctuations are gapless, low-energy excitations in the broken-symmetry state of magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry.
    *   They play an important role in diverse macroscopic properties, such as the existence of long-range order, order parameter magnitude, and temperature dependence.

*   **Importance of Transverse Spin Fluctuations in Magnetic Systems**
    *   Transverse spin fluctuations are crucial in understanding the behavior of magnetic systems, particularly in the antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.
    *   They are important in both two and three dimensions, where AF long-range order exists.

*   **Effect of Spin Fluctuations on Order Parameter and Néel Temperature**
    *   In the strong-coupling limit, spin fluctuations significantly reduce the zero-temperature AF order parameter in two dimensions to nearly 0.6 of the classical value.
    *   Similarly, the Néel temperature in three dimensions is reduced to nearly 0.7 of the mean-field result for the equivalent quantum Heisenberg antiferromagnet (QHA).

*   **Spin Fluctuations due to Defects, Disorder, and Vacancies**
    *   Spin fluctuations are also affected by defects, disorder, and vacancies in the quantum antiferromagnet.
    *   The random-α model, where α is set to zero on a fraction of sites, shows an enhancement of the lattice-averaged AF order parameter for small vacancy concentrations.

*   **Method for Evaluating Transverse Spin Correlations and Quantum Spin-Fluctuation Corrections**
    *   A new method is developed to evaluate transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections about the Hartree-Fock (HF) level broken-symmetry state.
    *   The method is applicable in the whole range of interaction strength and is illustrated with three applications involving the AF ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.

*   **Results for Transverse Spin Fluctuations and Sublattice Magnetization**
    *   The method is used to obtain quantum corrections to sublattice magnetization solely in terms of transverse spin correlations.
    *   Results show that the sublattice magnetization is reduced due to spin fluctuations, particularly in the strong-coupling limit.

*   The study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory has received much attention in various areas of physics, particularly in cosmology.
    *   The work has been driven largely by inflation, the most successful known mechanism for explaining the large-scale homogeneity and isotropy of the universe.
    *   The study of multi-field models of inflation has been of particular interest, as they can lead to a variety of features unavailable in the case of a single field.
    *   The subsequent phase of energy transfer between the inflaton and other degrees of freedom leading to the standard picture of big bang cosmology has been the subject of intense study.
    *   The inflaton may decay through perturbative processes as well as non-perturbative parametric amplification, which can lead to explosive particle production and very efficient reheating of the universe.

*   The study of hybrid inflation and reheating models has been of interest, as they both involve the coupling of two or more dynamical, interacting scalar fields.
    *   An important aspect of such systems is the possibility of mixing between the fields, which can lead to a variety of features unavailable in the case of a single field.
    *   The problem of renormalization of time evolution equations in single field models was understood several years ago, but the extension to multi-field models is more complicated.
    *   A new approach to renormalization has been developed, which relies on a formal perturbative expansion in the effective masses and time derivatives of the masses of the fields.
    *   This approach allows for the extraction of the divergent parts of the integrals that are to be removed via renormalization.

*   The study of a two-field case has been of particular interest, as it is often encountered in cosmological multi-field models for inflation.
    *   The physical applications of the problem have been discussed, including the study of a simple two-field model and a supersymmetric hybrid inflationary model.
    *   The results show that the mixing effects in the broad resonance regime are significant, leading to copious particle production and a rapid variation in the mixing angle.
    *   The study of a supersymmetric hybrid inflationary model has shown that the fluctuations can alter the coupling constants in such a way that the trajectory of the zero modes becomes irregular.
    *   The results have implications for the production of quanta from the vacuum fluctuations and the post-inflationary radiation era of the universe.

*   The existence of dark matter has been established, and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment.
    *   The weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP) is a promising candidate for dark matter if the essence of dark matter is an elementary particle.
    *   The WIMP dark matter candidate can be accommodated economically by introducing an inert scalar field.
    *   The imposed parity ensures the stability of the dark matter candidate.

*   The Higgs Triplet Model (HTM) is a simple model for generating neutrino masses, but it does not contain a dark matter candidate.
    *   The HTM introduces a triplet of complex scalar fields with hypercharge 2 to the Standard Model (SM).
    *   The triplet has a new Yukawa interaction term with leptons, which generates Majorana neutrino masses.
    *   The scalar potential in the HTM includes terms that involve the triplet field and the SM Higgs field.

*   The HTM has a characteristic feature that the structure of the neutrino mass matrix is given by that of the Yukawa matrix.
    *   The direct information on the neutrino mass matrix would be extracted from the decay of the doubly charged component of the triplet field.
    *   The searches at the LHC put a lower bound on the mass of the doubly charged component.
    *   The triplet scalars can contribute to lepton flavor violation (LFV) in decays of charged leptons.

*   The HTM has a problem that the lepton number conserving parameter is not naturally small.
    *   The parameter is assumed to be tiny in the HTM, but there is no reason why it should be tiny.
    *   The parameter is naturally small in the model presented below because it arises at the one-loop level.

*   The model presented below extends the HTM by introducing a singlet scalar field that breaks lepton number conservation.
    *   The singlet field has a non-zero lepton number and is electrically neutral.
    *   The lepton number conserving operator that results in the parameter is of dimension-5.
    *   The dimension-5 operator is obtained at the loop level by using renormalizable interactions of the singlet field.

*   The model has a dark matter candidate that is made from the real inert singlet scalar and the doublet scalar field.
    *   The interaction that is the origin of the parameter is induced at the one-loop level.
